Posts.Content: Oct 6, 2015 10:37AM Totoro wrote: Sometimes lumps and bumps are just normal breast tissue. I have a lumpy area right where you described yours and I had it examined. Was told it was breast tissue. It freaked me out when I first found it but now I'm more familiar with my breasts and what is normal for them and not normal. That's frustrating about the other finding though. Glad they are on top of it! Most likely it's a cyst or some other benign finding.

Posts.Content: Totoro wrote: I had both tests today due to increasingly intesifying breast pain and a lump I found. The pain is awful and keeping me awake at night and shoots into my armpit as well as constant stabbing burning stabbyness. Anyway, the doc I initially saw couldnt feel the lump but spent two seconds trying. The tech felt both the lump I felt and another pea sized lump nearby. I am 30 btw. The mammogram and ultrasound came back clear saying that my breasts are hetergenously dense and I got a BIRADS of 1 obviously. So what does it mean? They said come back when I'm 40 unless anything changes before then. I am left with more questions than answers. My pain is leaving me in tears, the lump hasn't gone anywhere, and I am confused. Posts.Content: Oct 7, 2015 06:47PM Totoro wrote: Are you running a fever? The most likely cause would be an infection, perhaps mastitis. If it gets worse you might want to get in to urgent care.
Posts.Title: Swollen Breast, pain - SCARED! TNS4life TNS4life

Posts.Content: Totoro wrote: Next thursday I head in to a breast clinic for another mammogram and ultrasound. My ND referred me there and hopefully I can get to the bottom of things. I have gotten to know my little lump quite well. And I have to say that he does NOT improve with time. He is a pain and an unwanted guest. I think he took residence in there six months ago because that's when the pain began but I didn't find the bugger until last month. He's hard as flint. No matter what I do to get him to move, he just sits there. He was hoping to go unoticed because he is deep in my boob but nothing escapes me forever! All joking aside I can feel the fear and anxiety well up inside me sometimes. Hard, immovable, fixed against my chest wall, can feel one edge clearly but the rest of the lump blends in to the surrounding tissue/muscle, lump itself isn't painful but breast is, localized unilateral breast pain for six freakin months.... I mean, the list of symptoms runs through my head and I can't help but go there. I guess I am looking for kind words of support to help me through this wait. And any bit of reality I will gladly take thrown my way too. Crazy as it may sound, my big fear for my appointment next week is that imaging won't visualize it. I want to SEE what this lump is. I want a medical professional to see it. At least my ND felt it so I'm not imagining it. Log in to post a reply

Posts.Title: Waiting for imaging (take 2) and going crazy Totoro Totoro

Posts.Content: Sep 10, 2013 02:55PM Totoro wrote: Well now don't jump to conclusions! (pot, meet kettle... ) but eczema is really common and usually caused by a food allergy, especially if you've had it for a while. Creases tend to get it more too! My son had awful eczema until we cut out wheat and dairy. Just a thought! Of course doc should be informed. I swear, in this day and age it seems as if we know more than the professionals do. It blows me away how ill and under informed medical professionals really can be. Ugh. And I am like you, I'd rather know all the details of what 'could' hapen so I am informed and not over run by info overload if/when the time comes.

Posts.Title: Waiting for imaging (take 2) and going crazy Totoro Totoro

Posts.Content: Sep 13, 2013 02:50AM Totoro wrote: Just got back from imaging. Everything looked normal. Both techs could feel the lump. The ultrasound tech put the wand directly over the lump but still could see nothing. She told me if she were in my shoes, she would pursue more testing, that ultrasounds and mammograms can miss palpable lumps sometimes. And that I need to follow up with my doc to see what's next. I am so discouraged and frustrated that I am still no nearer to figuring out what's wrong. My breast hurts worse everyday. I have a lump everyone can feel but no one can see. Could it be that it's just a lump of normal tissue all balled together and that's why it's invisible? I was hoping they would see that it was a fibroadenoma or SOMEthing to explain the pain. So here I sit, contemplating calling my doc and oushing for more testing or just trusting that this is my new normal.
Posts.Title: Waiting for imaging (take 2) and going crazy Totoro Totoro

Posts.Content: Oct 24, 2015 01:06AM Totoro wrote: It could be that it's just breast tissue. I have fibrocystic tissue in my breasts and had a lump excised because it couldn't be seen on imaging. That's how I found out, it was just normal tissue, nothing to see. Not seen on MRI probably means it is just your breast tissue. Good luck!

Posts.Title: the waiting is over jushavinfun Totoro

Posts.Content: Oct 17, 2013 08:32AM Totoro wrote: Wanted to update. I had an appointment with the breast surgeon and she said all of the above indicates fibrocystic changes so it is all completely normal technical terms for fibrocystic breasts! Best of all, none of it increases risks for cancer in the future. Evening primrose oil should help with pain but lumps will likely recur she said. So for anyone searching the sbove terms, now you know! Thanks for all the support here. So appreciated!
Posts.Title: Pathology report back! Deciphering help Totoro Beesie

Posts.Content: Totoro wrote: I love online chart access! First and foremost, B9! But quite busy! I am slightly confused about what it all means. Breast tissue showing fibrocystic changes including usual ductal hyperplasia, columnar cell changes and areas of fibrotic stroma consistent with scattered PASH. Mild scattered nonspecific periductal chronic inflammation with associated luminal hemorrhage and histocytes present. No papilloma, in situ or invasive carcinoma identified. All margins of excision are negative for malignancy. The slides contain a hemorrhagic area. So I know none of this is malignant obviously but what is up with the hemorrhage and inflammation? And I know I have heard PASH thrown around as well as UDH and CCC. Any insight? Log in to post a reply
